posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
/r9k/ is an imageboard where there are no exact reposts.

1. If you attempt to post something unoriginal, it is not posted, and you are muted temporarily.
2. The time with which you are muted for doubles with each transgression.
3. Each mute time is 2^n in seconds where n is the number of times you have transgressed. So, your mute time doubles each time you fuck up.
4. Backlinks, eg >>1, are not viewed by the robot. So "lolwut" and ">>2 lolwut" are the same post, in the eyes of the robot.
5. Gibberish at the end of a post to force originality may result in mod intervention (no BLOX posts please).
6. Images are NOT included in the filter, only text.
7. Your mute count slowly decreases over time.
8. You cannot post a picture without text.
9. Unicode is blocked. Sorry, too many exploits (Cyrillic letters, etc).
10. Posts require a certain minimum amount of original content in order to be posted.
11. Post sane, real content, well thought out replies, and mutes are unlikely.
12. The original algorithm was designed by XKCD:
http://blag.xkcd.com/2008/01/14/robot9000-and-xkcd-signal-attacking-noise-in-chat/

No, why does everyone always want to start murdering people?

First, we'd eliminate most restrictions on company housing. There would need to be some regulation drawn up to prevent previous abuses. Next, rents for apartments and single family homes would be capped as a flat percentage of the median income with locales being permitted to make adjustments as they deemed necessary for their cities and regions over time. Finally, we'd need to pass some long overdue financial regulation to eliminate the harmful practice of accruing debt to purchase additional rental properties while being a very high risk borrower on paper with some truly terrifying fines for lenders caught breaking the rules. There would likely still be some landlords, but most of the current social and economic ills would be adequately addressed. I think that it goes without saying that all suggested changes be implemented gradually, save for the desperately needed lending reforms. Oh, and property tax for residential property simply needs to die.

The result in the end would be decreased wage growth, increased consumer spending, and shorter commutes.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>71727472
This. We can discourage the harmful practices and regulate rates, but the ideal with any change is slow evolution toward the preferred outcome. I think the largest two problems when it comes to rent are city rental buildings and single family homes. The former is pretty easy to address. Control rental rates to give businesses some relief and limit urban inflationary pressure, but lower the various taxes that building owners pay. For single family homes, a full transition to rent to own with evictions barred except for nonpayment would allow a very gentle phaseout without any major fireworks. Standardize the term, but allow landlords to charge more than the assessed value of the home with a reasonable cap. This allows for a revenue stream to remain in real estate, works toward eliminating lifelong renting, and still allows for credit challenged people to obtain single family housing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
CONTINUED

For example, whenever I hugged her, increasingly more often, she always shows reciprocity without delay, but in a very robotic way. I hug, she hugs. I let go, she lets go. She never initiates, but also never shows any resistance whatsoever. Our hugs just dont matter much to her. The frightening part is I probably could touch her in an inappropriate way and she would probably barely react.

Ask her directly:
"Do you even feel anything when we hug?"
"I think I enjoy the tactile sensation."
Ugh. So technical and definitely not romantic.

Later:
"You said you often have trouble understanding what people feel and want. Do you think you understand me?"
"I have heard you talk a lot, and I analyzed your voice and body language, so I think I do."
(No, you dont, I thought, there is no way you realize how much you mean to me.)

Then:
"You are always so rational. Do you have emotions at all?"
"You ask questions. I think I do, but I would prefer not having them. They are just annoying and prevent me from acting rational."

Before we part:
"Are you interested in men at all? Do you feel that kind of desire?"
"I collect information about them. Otherwise, I dont think. No idea what you wanna hear."

The disheartening part she did not even understand the weight of my question. She continued talking in her usual tone, even though I almost proposed to her, in a way.

>I realize she may not be simply weird, but emotionally stunted or even asexual. Which is a common correlate of Aspergers and also the sole explanation why a girl so pretty is so lonely and willing to hang out with me nonstop.
>(That OR she friendzoned me. I do not believe it, as she just seems like an Aspie all around, ticking almost all boxes.)

tldrm I met a girl that is surreal, intelligent and erudite, very pretty AND likes me back and is willing to spend most of her free time with me. But she is Aspie/asexual. Or potentially sexual in an subdued way, not for me.

I was SO close to something so beautiful.

>>71726404
I don't know how you would have to go about easing into it, it is tough.

When I was unemployed in my 20s after graduating for nearly 2 years I felt worthless and was cooped up in my room most of the time on my PC browsing or playing video games, outside of family didn't talk to people much besides sending out applications and the rare phone call for a job application.
One way I managed to break a bit out of my shell a little was to get enrolled into a hospitality course, it got me interacting with people I was training with, learned how to make coffee, some cocktails, how to serve customers in a restaurant.
Then had to do some voluntary work as a part of that course in different taverns, functions, and resturants.
I ended up getting a proper full time job unrelated to hospitality shortly after completing it but at least it got me talking to people out there. When I started full time work I was shy and nervous but over time conversing, stuffing up a bit here and there and adjusting, observing other people and subconciously figuring out certain habits you eventually get the hang of it.

Usually when everyone is working on a common goal and physically present that is when you naturally tend to bump into people and converse.
School, University, Work, clubs (martial arts, RC racing/flying) or hell even some outdoor activities like fishing you get people randomly walk up to you for a chat about your catch that turns into a different conversation.
There are plenty of ways to get into contact with people but most involve performing some sort of activity in public with or in the vicinity of other people.

It is not a skill you instantly get good at, but with enough exposure you can become adept.

>>71726541
I think you have morals and ethics confused. Those two terms are often used interchangeably though, so it's a common mistake. See morals are like our principle beliefs in right and wrong. Morals are also subjective, because individuals will have different ideas of what constitutes right and wrong. Ethics are more like generally accepted social rules. Like things you should and shouldn't do. A person who has strong morals may have no ethics, which means they aren't restrained by doing things a lot of people would believe is "wrong" but done in order to achieve the greater good. Someone with no morals generally has no ethics, though.

As I said, morals are subjective, so the villain in someone's view may be the hero to others. I can be both a hero and a villain or be none at all. So can you.

Are you a hero or a villain? Sounds like neither to me, since you're "flexible"

>>71640933
>w-whats the flower thing all about
It's a theory that categorizes people by their sensitivity and resilience! ^o^
Originally, it was just "dandelion children", which meant people who thrived in spite of having grown up in extremely hard conditions; this term was apparently coined in Sweden in the 1980s ( and I presume it originally referred to people akin to the "super thrivers" Will Marre discusses here: https://real-leaders.com/one-thing-everyone-should-know/ )! In 1996, Elaine Aron published a book about highly sensitive people, simply named The Highly Sensitive Person! And nine years later, Bruce Ellis and W. Thomas Boyce published a paper titled "Biological sensitivity to context" (2005), where they dubbed highly sensitive people "orchid children" and the meaning of "dandelion child" basically changed to refer to anyone who isn't an "orchid"! Finally, in January 2018, a group of researchers led by Francesca Lionetti published their article in Translational Psychiatry and introduced a third group: "tulip children", which has both resilient and sensitive characteristics (by the way, Elaine Aron is one of the authors of this paper~): https://rdcu.be/c2MtB ! \(^_^)/
So tl;dr:
>dandelion: high resilience, low sensitivity
>tulip: medium resilience, medium sensitivity
>orchid: low resilience, high sensitivity
*^w^*
You can take the flower test here: https://sensitivityresearch.com/self-tests/adult-self-test/

>whats you favourite one
Maybe spearmint! :3

>your type
INFP 4w5
>What were you like as a kid?
Up and down. Sometimes excited, friendly, outgoing, and other times withdrawn, scared, anxious. Sometimes I wanted to see people, sometimes I wanted to be alone in nature. No matter what I was always lost in the inner recesses of my mind. Visions of grand battles against evil for my family and country swept over me daily. Feeling like I had a family. That and being lost in my head without a care in the world while spending the weekend at my grandma's

As for things I miss... I don't know. I kind of miss not having incredibly intense anger issues, as I've had in my 20s and 30s. I kind of miss not easily entering states of seething anger and hatred that can take me hours to escape from and which leave me physically exhausted when I finally do so.

>>71698570
I've heard conflicting reports on how kids were treated in olden times. The "little adults" idea largely hinges on exactly what age we're talking about. 11 year olds? Yeah, maybe. 3 year olds? No, toddlers are the furthest thing in the world from "miniature adults" on just about every possible level.

The impression I get is that the maturation process went at an accelerated rate compared to today, but that there was still a transition from child to adult that spanned years. Children in ancient fiction are still portrayed as mischievous, bratty, and dumb. 6 year olds worked hard on the farm rather than taking it easy, but they didn't hold significant ranks in society and were often considered not to be culpable for crimes. 11 year olds worked on the mines, but that didn't mean they were viewed 1:1 identical to adults psychologically - just that they were capable of doing manual labor. From what I can gather, many societies viewed people as full adults in the 14-18 range, not well into the 20s like today, but people below that range weren't viewed as adults. It's true that 'child culture' wasn't much of a thing back then - kids wore smaller versions of adult clothes, they didn't have media specifically catered to them - but I don't think it's humanly possible not to realize that a 5 year old is very difficult from someone in their 20s or 30s, no matter what the culture or era.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71698864
>Would people be ok with any other demographic being forced into education camps? Yeah, didn't think so.
I strongly agree with this, though. I think kids and adults are different and have to be treated differently, but that doesn't mean the way we treat them is good. I have always been incredibly uncomfortable with the idea of forcing kids into 13 years of compulsory education, 13 straight years of 40 hour weeks. Even if you excuse this as a necessary evil for society to function, I still think many parents don't give their kids enough freedom, scheduling out their every single hour and waking moment, trying to sign them up for every extracurricular possible to turn them into a Renaissance kid of a thousand skills regardless of their own personality or interests or desires. Kids aren't adult but they're still human beings. They should have choices, they should have a significant amount of freedom, they should have their preferences and feelings respected and listened to. They can't be given free reign and have to be guided to some extent, but too many parents treat their kids as though they're dolls to play with with no free will of their own.

-Side note:
This made me think of why we don't refer to mothers carrying children as something.

When you add components together to build an entity (aka a car), those components become one unit. The wheels and the steering wheel are the same thing. They are one unit. A car. Whilst in the configuration "car" they are the same exact thing. If you remove the components, they "revert" to their previous state. But, unlike our egg, or (you), they cannot be reassembled to recreate the entity.

>EIther two things are actually the same thing, or they aren't.
Naive and wrong. Two things can be different and also be the same thing. A wheel and a steering wheel. Not the same things whilst they're separate. But when they're together they are the same thing, a car.

>The whole is greater than the sum of its parts
This line deals with this exact concept. When two or more components come together to create something new, the components no longer exist on an individual level. They only exist as the unit.

>In his foreword Jung begins by acknowledging the difficulties that have kept him from publishing this material to date. These include feelings of inadequacy, especially of his scientific training (obviously he was bolstered by publishing together with Pauli; however, he was never comfortable with math and physics, his background was in the biological sciences). He cites three reasons for proceeding: (1) His increasing experience of and with the phenomena. (2) His research into the history of fish symbolism (presented in detail in his book Aion), which included a set of synchronicities - in addition to those in the published accounts, Jung found a snake that had choked in the act of swallowing a fish so that both had died. This occurred in 1933 at the shore by his Bollingen retreat. According to a family member, Jung saw this as a synchronicity since he was working on the relationship of Christianity/Fish and Alchemy/Snake at the time, and the external event paralleled his views on how these systems' inability to integrate their perspectives was fatal to each, leaving them dead. This conjunction so impressed Jung that he carved the image of the snake swallowing the fish into a block of stone that serves as part of the base for the loggia at Bollingen (fig. 1). (3) His realization that he had been "alluding to the existence of this phenomenon on and off in my writing for twenty years without discussing it any further."
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/26905461_Synchronicity_Nature_and_Psyche_in_an_Interconnected_Universe

>>71704263
>You can easily say fuel is not part of the car
That is only true if the fuel is outside of the car. Without the fuel, the car cannot be a car. That is to say it cannot serve the function of a car, which is to create motion.
If you turn a gas powered car into an electric car, the concept becomes more visible. Fuel is replaced by electricity, and the fuel tank is replaced by a battery. Then you can expand the concept to include humans as "electric cars", we have batteries which hold electricity which we use to generate motion. Is the electricity that's surging through your nerves right now part of you?
If yes, then the fuel of a car is part of the car. If yes, then the animal (or plant) that you consumed to create that electricity is also part of you.
>It reminds me of some philosophy courses I took in uni.
These are the sorts of things that occupy my mind the majority of the time. Maybe I should go study philosophy.
>You seem to think that the function is what gives an object its object-ness
That wasn't my stance, that was actually theirs, found here: >>71701395

The idea of defining an object by its functionality seemed interesting to me, so I did a devils advocate to take it on as my own point of in order to challenge and understand anon's perception to see what they actually believed and object was defined by. My definition of what an objects object-ness is by analyzing its components. A car that is missing four wheels is not a car. It's missing the defining feature of a car, which is wheels. It was a car, prior to having its wheels removed. Just like a person who has had their "consciousness" evaporated is no longer a person, they're just a dead body.
If you added new wheels to your car, that is not the same car anymore. Just like if you injected a new consciousness into that body, it's not the same person anymore.

>>71709496
Extraverted sensation is the sensing function that perceives sensations from the external world in an objective manner. For example, since an extraverted sensors type's source of reward gravitates around perceiving and feeling external phenomena, he often has a good sense of aesthetic - whether this be the taste of food, or a new trend in clothing. Extraverted Sensors may be more attuned with spatial awareness and physical reality. Note that a bodily sensation is still considered extraverted sensing, as the sensation is being perceived in objective reality. Such as, drinking caffeine will objectively create a stimulating sensation in the person's physiology. This is contrasted to the subjective sensor who may be concerned with a subjective response to the same drink (e.g. nostalgia that is tied to that specific cup of coffee, or whether or not they prefer the flavor)

> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jungian_cognitive_functions#Extraverted_sensation

>>71710287
>blood isn't analogous to fuel
That isn't the point I was trying to make, it was a comparison. The two liquids serve different purposes, but that is irrelevant. The point I was making is that they're both liquids enclosed in a system, and since they're part of that system they are that system.
The blood in your veins is you.
The gasoline inside of your car is your car.
The water in the ocean is the planet, just as much as the dirt, the trees, the buildings, you, me, and this computer. Just like you are the cancer cell that is growing inside of you right now, you are the bacteria in your stomach and the hair on your head. Every component of something is the entire thing.
>resuscitation.
Resuscitation is a medical act, not a state of being. It's something that is done to you by someone else. If someone gives you CPR, you're being resuscitated. If you can be in the state of being "dying", there must be the opposite of "dying". Which means there are four states of "alive". Which are: alive, dying, [the opposite of dying], dead.
>i don't understand how it could be ambiguous
The same way we can disagree about whether or not the gasoline is part of a car. I don't know what you define as "all of the parts of myself", as everyone defines the entire entity of "myself" as different things. I can assure you, without a shadow of a doubt, my definition of "all of myself" is not the same as yours. I can't nitpick your list of yourself, because I am not you. I can however highlight the differences is how we view the entity "myself" through contrast, which you could possibly perceive as disagreement. Although it is not.
>it's obvious what makes a person.
It most certainly is not. I don't have the room in this post to explain it though.
>too much zombie tv
I don't actually watch any zombie anything. Un-dead means alive, but in a certain context. It means you were previously dead. Someone who has not died is not un-dead, they're just alive.

There's something like a dozen signs that go into someone's astrology chart, of which Rising is one.

The Sun sign is your general, overall personality
The Moon sign describes your emotions
The Rising sign describes your demeanor, and how you appear to others. I'm an Aries Rising, which probably doesn't fit.
The Mercury sign is about friendships - your desires, preferences, etc
Venus is like Mercury but centers around romance
Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, and Pluto also have their own signs, but I don't know what they represent.

>I had at least 10 000 letters of text
This was a message from your unconscious, trying to point you in the correct direction. But, the unconscious doesn't have access to the speech parts of the brain so the only way it can communicate is through images. The reason it feels like Excalibur is because you're literally trying to reach into your unconscious mind and consciously pull things out. That won't work.
If you want to pull from those unconscious images, you need to relax the conscious grip on the mind and allow it to flow like water. Your reflex will be to consciously grip and like water, the images will shoot in a million different directions. (Literally go put your hand in a bowl of water and then quickly completely close your hand if you can't visualize this)
What you need is a box, or a bowl or some container for all the letters to relax in that way you can observe them in their natural state. Like watching a river flow, but the river is your own mind. Maybe you literally need to put the letters in a big river and see where that river goes.

>>71726342
That is also something I was trying to explain, but I lack meaningful words to do so. The main thing is to look internally towards the driving motives for these behaviors. The word I used was "spark" when I initially explained this a few threads ago.

>Find spark that creates negative response
>Trigger response in a place where you feel safe so that the fight or flight response isn't extreme
>Find the place of origin of the spark (why it happens)
>Trigger spark in no consequence scenario where the goal is to just sit in the negative emotion without reacting to the fight or flight emotion (to see that nothing bad will happen, and everything is alright)
>Slowly build up the stakes increasing the difficulty of the scenario to build tolerance to the spark
>Eventually the spark doesn't consume the conscious mind and is only a small passing feeling that can be brushed off in most scenarios
That's the basic idea. As with all psychological things, it's a very long process that is very easily disrupted.
>>71726491
>it doesnt work that way!
It does, I promise! Eventually you have to refocus you can't stay in a state of perpetual un-focused. Being unfocused is just so your conscious mind releases its hold on the brain and the unconscious will be the only thing present. When this happens, your focus is to observe your unconscious process like an outside observer of your own mind. Don't try to express or understand or judge the images you see, just let them be. As the images come, you'll have feelings or sensations, they're different for everyone. But the images that have feelings associated with them have been tied to that feeling, you just need to pull that feeling and the image will follow. It's sort of like a "jumpstart" for the unconscious process.
Eventually you can create the process with conscious images, but that takes lots and lots of practice. Fire is the image I use, that image is tied to a bunch of feelings tied to unconscious images.

>>71707191

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71707191
I spent the first 2-3 years regularily trying to cut all of this out of my life. I would spend a few days just pretending like I never had a waifu, like this character meant nothing to me. Eventually, I would get this strong feeling, I'd miss them.
I was afraid of "waifu" and anime fans, and thought it was the way to spiral to degeneracy and a failed life. I thought, maybe I could just snap out of it and stop being like that, I thought there's no way I fell in love unironically.
Nowadays, when I think about giving up what I feel, it feels rude, and like so much work. I found a warm side to lean on, maybe in an unusual way and place, maybe it's very out-of-character for who I normally am, but it's real nonetheless. Every bone in my body hated the life I live right now, and my waifu managed to convince all of them otherwise, one after the other.
I might have lost a bit of my rationality on the way, and I don't want to sound cheesy, but I think it was worth it.

posts.name: pizza delivery anon
posts.com:
yo when i was diagnosed at 14, it made me so anxious in school until college happened, i was afraid to even try reaching out and socializing because i was afraid that something i'd say or do would out me as an autismo.

Remember anon, that it's just a name they give to a set of behaviors. it doesn't define you, there's no documented neurological phenomenon that they can scan your brain and point to, and you're the same person you were before the diagnosis, with the exact same abilities and emotions. All the diagnosis should do is open some doors to some extra help for you, and make the people who are on your side more aware of what's going on. Don't use it as an excuse for why you can't do something and let it limit you, there is literally nothing you can't do because of your aspergers, and every challenge you face is something that can be overcome, even if you have to be creative to come up with a strategy for handling some things, or have to arrange slight accommodations with people you work with here and there. You'll be able to make it anon. Remember, you didn't change, you just identified something about yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hello, Anon, need some help? A shoulder to cry on? Sit down and let's have a little chat.

STEP #1, HYGIENE AND HOME:
Brush your teeth twice a day, morning and evening. Scrub'em good with all the movements you can think of, circles, up and down, lateral, front and behind. This will take somewhere around 2 minutes. Floss once a day.
Moisturize your face with a cream after washing your face in the morning.
Depending on how much you sweat shower every or every second day.
Get a haircut every 2 months. If you are balding just cut'em short, anything else looks shit and insecure about it.
If your clothes are ripped, stretched and discolored as shit, get some new ones. Basic, monotone, cheap shirts will do just fine. Again, depending on your sweat wear'em between 1 and 3 days, then change. If you got a pile of dirty rags wash it.

This brings us to your home. Doesn't matter if you live alone or with your parents, clean your dwelling once a week. Empty bottles and packages are to be thrown away immediately, instead of hoarded. It's no work if you do it this way. Used plates, glasses, etc., are to be washed off immediately after use. Again, if you do it like this, it's way less work than cleaning off a whole pile of them.
Changing bed sheets and vacuuming the place once a week.

A healthy mind lives in a clean body, living in a clean place. All that grime on yourself and around you poisons your mind. This regime gets rid of that without too much effort. You will also feel a sense of accomplishment, which boosts you for what comes next, LEAVING THE HOUSE

STEP #2, LEAVE HOUSE:
Go out every day. Do long walks of atleast 2 hours. Explore your city, your surroundings. Go into alleys you never walked before. Whenever you think, oh whats there or I never was there or anything similiat, thats where you go!
Do not ask yourself shit, like "whats the use? Enjoy the moment, do not drown out your surrounsings with your depressive thoughts.

FUFU

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
STEP #3, SOCIALIZE:
I want you to greet people on your walks. Not some barely audible mumble, but a clear greeting. Establish eye contact, throw'em a good day coupled with a nod or a quick wave. I want your face to glow and your voice to echoe joy when you do this. Doesnt matter if its forced and unnatural at first, its training, if it came natural to you we wouldn't have to have this conversation.

After a few weeks or months of doing everything I told you, you should feel better about yourself. You wont be chad, fucking bitches left and right and going through life constantly happy, but at leaat you wont feel absolutely miserable for once. You may be able to pull off more intense forms of socializing now.

Get into the habit of doing smalltalk with strangers, like cashiers or the people you meet on walks. It doesn't matter that it's benign and trivial shit, just do it. Observe them, what they wear, their hair, makeup, tatoos, whatever and throw them a compliment, ask them where they got it from, what meaning it holds to them. When the convo naturally found its end, say your goodbye and go on your way.

STEP #4, GET A REAL HOBBY:
You should be prepared now, physically and mentally, to go out there and take the risk of trying new stuff, which will include meeting people doing the same stuff, but you are ready for that.

Here are things I can vouche for: Bouldering/climbing, martial arts, swimming, biking, skating, going to a chess/go/shogi/mahjong/etc center where you can watch, learn and play. If you like reading, go to a library instead of doing it at home. Generally, I advise you to engage mind and body. Try several physical activities and intellectual/creative ones.

At this point it should become a self perpetuating cycle. Keep challenging yourself, keep experiencing,exploring and learning new things.
Learn to "live in the moment". Dont question the use or meaning, do not rationalize, try to let the stimuli wash over you like a river.

FUFIFU

>>71726660
Hi, Anon.

So you fear social interaction? Step 2 and 3 have been designed for you. Thhey are ontended as exposure therapy for people like you. Getting you used to it. You may never feel really comfy whem among others, and you'll never be an extrovert socialite, but at least you can get to a point where you do not spill all yoir spaghetti because someone talked to you.

Once you reach that point many doors will open for you in step 4. You can do way more tjings if you can stand to leave your home and be at places where other people are present.

Here is a rational argument that may help you to fave your fear in an attempt to overcome it. If you greet strangers, neighbors or employees at your local store, do a little chitchat with them and so on, what is the worst that can happen? Worst thing, they tjink you are weird. They most likely won't even articulate that judgement, so ot may as well be nonexistent. Even if they let you know, why should you care? Their opinion is of no consequence, nothing bad will happen to you from it.

Learning that, internalizing a sens of trust, that nothing happens just because someone doesn't like you, is crucial and will hopefully lead to a betterment of your condition.

If you do not want to do it that is regretable, but doesn't mean you can not participate on our thread. If you need to vent, I'll listen. If you need advise, I'll help of I can. If you have tips for people like you, since you've been battling your condition, you're welcome to give them to those in need. If you just wanna talk a little, because you are lonely, we are here.
Anyway, welcome to the NHK, Anon, glad to have you around.

Whites, naturally, were outnumbered, so they'd give special privileges to whatever group they liked best and that privileged indigenous group would oppress the others. The natives of Northern Nigeria were the opposite. They were Muslim, which meant they were a bit more technologically advanced but incredibly socially backwards when compared to the southerners. Their government was monarchic. Those who weren't part of the royal family and weren't part of the elite class were basically just slaves. They had no education and had no say in anything regarding their civilization.
